skill.name: clean-code
skill.description: Clean code principles for readable, maintainable software
skill.summary: Clean code principles for readable, maintainable software
skill.author: Benny9193

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown content with TypeScript code examples. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, no external commands, no environment variable access. Content matches stated purpose of providing clean code principles. All 54 static findings are false positives - the scanner incorrectly flagged TypeScript code examples in documentation as security threats.

content.value_statement: Code is read far more often than it is written. This skill helps you write code that humans can understand. It provides proven principles for naming, functions, comments, and error handling that improve code readability and maintainability.
actual_capabilities: Guide naming conventions for variables, functions, and booleans
Explain single responsibility principle for functions
Provide guidance on avoiding flag arguments and excessive parameters
Recommend early return patterns to reduce nesting
Outline when to use comments versus self-documenting code
Describe error handling best practices including null handling
limitations: Does not automatically refactor or modify your code
Does not execute or test code changes
Does not integrate with IDEs or build tools
Does not generate code from scratch

use_cases.title: Refactor Legacy Code
use_cases.description: Apply clean code principles to improve readability and maintainability of existing codebases.

use_cases.title: Evaluate Code Quality
use_cases.description: Use checklists and guidelines to assess pull requests for code quality and adherence to standards.

use_cases.title: Learn Good Habits
use_cases.description: Develop strong coding habits early by following established clean code conventions and patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code for clean code principles. Are the names clear? Does each function do one thing?

prompt_templates.title: Refactor Guidance
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me refactor this function to follow clean code principles. Suggest better names and structure.

prompt_templates.title: Naming Patterns
prompt_templates.prompt: What are better names for these variables and functions to make the code self-documenting?

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Does this module follow single responsibility? What functions should be extracted and why?

output_examples.input: Help me improve this function: function process(data) { if (data.active) { doThing(); doOtherThing(); } }
output: Rename 'process' to describe the specific action like 'activateItems'
Split into separate functions if 'doThing' and 'doOtherThing' are unrelated
Use early return pattern for clarity
Rename 'data' to describe what it contains, e.g., 'user' or 'inventoryItem'

best_practices: Use descriptive names that reveal intent and can be searched for easily
Keep functions small with a single responsibility and minimal parameters
Leave code cleaner than you found it with small, incremental improvements
anti_patterns: Writing comments to explain confusing code instead of rewriting it
Using magic numbers and strings without named constants
Passing null values that require runtime checks and throw errors

faq.question: Which programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: Principles apply to all languages. Examples use TypeScript but concepts transfer to Python, Java, Go, and others.

faq.question: Does this skill work with specific AI coding tools?
faq.answer: Yes. Designed for Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Works with any AI assistant that helps write or review code.

faq.question: Can this skill automatically fix my code?
faq.answer: No. It provides guidance and recommendations. You apply the suggestions to your code manually or with your editor.

faq.question: Is my code data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based skill with no code execution or network access. Code is processed only in your chat context.

faq.question: How is this different from linters and formatters?
faq.answer: Linters enforce syntax rules. This skill addresses higher-level design choices like naming, structure, and intent.

faq.question: Should I follow these principles strictly?
faq.answer: Use judgment. Principles are guidelines, not rules. Apply them where they improve clarity for your team and codebase.
